Judul: Probability of error for M-branch macroscopic selection diversity
Abstrak:
Diversity is a well known technique to
mitigate the deleterious effects of the radio
channel as it can reduce the signal variability.
However, the improvement in performance
obtainable from the use of microscopic diversity is
related to the standard deviation (a) of the lognormal
component, the improvement decreasing
as a increases. In this paper a closed-form analytical
solution is obtained for the performance of Mbranch
macroscopic selection diversity. It has
been found that a composite Rayleigh plus lognormal
distribution can be accurately approximated
by another log-normal distribution. The
results indicate that for a BER of and
U = 9 dB, a 2-branch macroscopic diversity offers
an improvement of 13 dB. Unlike microscopic
diversity, the performance improvement of an Mbranch
macroscopic system increases as a
increases. The results also show that, for the same
number of branches, macroscopic outperforms
microscopic diversity and the composite microscopic
plus macroscopic systems.
